body.header: Read this sample answer to the writing task in the previous exercise. Complete the composition by choosing the word or phrase which best fits each gap.

section.p: The burgeoning number of distance-learning courses available on the Internet has led some people to speculate that the future of education is 'online'. However, enthusiasm for this""their""such"" mode of learning is not universal, and many people feel that the limitations of online education mean that it""they""these"" should never replace traditional classroom teaching altogether.

Advocates of online learning argue that the replacement of conventional classroom-based learning with wholly online courses would bring""brought""would have brought"" both pedagogical and practical benefits. It is claimed""claims""has claimed"", for example, that such""their""this"" courses would allow students to organise their study programme and set the pace of their learning to suit themselves""them""those"". In addition, they would be able to concentrate and work more easily in the comfort of their""whose""your"" own homes. It is also argued that online tutors would be able to provide students with far more individual attention than is possible in conventional classroom situations. Finally, it is often""always""seldom"" suggested that education providers would""must""should"" benefit because they""these""those"" could run online courses at a fraction of the cost of employing classroom teachers and operating premises.

Despite these""their""those"" potential benefits, sceptics give equally convincing reasons why""which""that"" this new educational trend should not be allowed to replace classrooms and teachers entirely. Firstly, it is generally agreed""argued""pointed out"" that learning best takes place in environments where""which""whose"" students work face-to-face in groups, sharing ideas and knowledge and solving learning problems together. This kind of interaction, it is said, would not be possible over the Internet. Secondly, a requirement of online learning is familiarity with computers and computer software, but not everyone feels comfortable using this technology. If courses were""are""had been"" only available online, students who""which""they"" are not so at ease using computers would be severely disadvantaged. Finally, many courses involve hands-on practical work and it is widely""greatly""highly"" believed that this""a""such"" kind of practical experience, which""that""(...)"" is an essential part of many subjects from natural sciences to vocational training, could not be provided over the Internet.

On balance, I would say that educational establishments should""will""would"" include both online and traditional face-to-face elements in the courses they provide. In this way, students would benefit from the more personalised learning that Internet courses offer without losing opportunities for face-to-face interaction with fellow students and valuable practical work.

p.font: this: This is the correct answer.
their/such: The missing word refers to 'online' learning.
it: This is the correct answer.
they/these: The missing word refers to 'education', a noun which is uncountable.
would bring: This is the correct answer.
brought: The 'conditional' form of the verb is needed here. This sentence doesn't have an 'if' clause.
would have brought: 'would + have + past participle' is used to make hypotheses about the past. This is not the case here.
is claimed: This is the correct answer.
claims/has claimed: Passive voice is needed here.
such: This is the correct answer.
their: Whose courses? You don't need the possessive pronoun here.
this: The following noun, 'courses', is plural.
themselves: This is the correct answer.
them/those: The missing pronoun refers back to the students. You need the reflexible pronoun.
their: This is the correct answer.
whose/your: The students' homes.
often: This is the correct answer.
always: This would be an exaggeration.
seldom: If a point is 'seldom suggested' it probably isn't worth mentioning.
would: This is the correct answer.
must/should: Which modal verb is used to describe hypothetical situations?
they: This is the correct answer.
these/those: The missing word refers to 'education providers', which means people such as teachers. You need the plural subject pronoun.
these: This is the correct answer.
their/those: The missing word refers back to the benefits listed in the previous paragraph. It's quite a 'close' reference.
why: This is the correct answer.
which/that: Note that the word before the gap is 'reasons'.
agree: This is the correct answer.
argued/pointed out: We can say 'often argued' but not 'generally argued'.
where: This is the correct answer.
which/whose: 'Environments' are places.
were: This is the correct answer.
are: A hypothetical situation is being described here.
had been: The writer is not discussing a situation in the past.
who: This is the correct answer.
which: The missing pronoun refers to people â€“ students.
they: This is a relative clause.
widely: This is the correct answer.
this: This is the correct answer.
which: This is the correct answer.
that/(...): This is a non-defining relative clause.
should: This is the correct answer.
will/would: The writer is making a suggestion.
